utterances: But it still did damage.
Michael Sylve is looking out at homes marooned on their foundations by two or three feet of water in Plaquemines Parish, La., out on the Mississippi River Delta.
Oh, a huge mess.
A huge mess.
The storm surge poured in through a gap in the levee here at West Pointe a la Hache, La.
Now, where I'm standing, there are sandbags plugging the gap.
But water poured through here because the levee wasn't finished.
There was an open hole in it, and people here are angry about that.
They never finished their job.
And now I can't get into my home without a boat.
Janet Sylve's trailer home rests on seven-foot-tall concrete pillars.
Floodwaters climbed maybe half that distance.
And she thinks her place is OK, but as of this morning, she hadn't been back inside since evacuating Thursday.
She's got good reason not to wade out there.
We have a 12-foot alligator back there about a couple of months ago, so I know he's floated up somewhere - where, I can't tell you.
(Laughter) So you don't want to go in there.
So I don't want to go in the water, correct (laughter).
Other parts of the coast also saw storm surges top levees and water rushing over roads.
At the height of the storm, the Coast Guard rescued several people from Terrebonne Parish.
Lake Pontchartrain pushed into some shoreline homes.
Winds gusting up to 70 miles an hour took down trees and knocked more than 150,000 homes and businesses off the power grid at one point.
The international airport in New Orleans and much of the rest of the city were closed Saturday.
The storm is pushing on north, dumping heavy rain on saturated ground, high lakes and flooding rivers.
Lieutenant Chaun Domingue with the Plaquemines Parish Sheriff's Department is glad to see the end of Barry on the coast.
It could have been a lot worse.
I think in a couple days, we might be past this.
So it could've been a whole lot worse.
We're very fortunate.
This time - as Domingue points out, it's just the early part of the hurricane season.
For NPR News, I'm Frank Morris in West Pointe a la Hache, La.
This is Day to Day.
I'm Alex Cohen.
In St. Louis, teenage peer pressure has taken a violent turn.
Street gangs are recruiting adolescents and kids, some as young as elementary schoolers.
From member station KWMU, Adam Allington reports.
In a windowless interior office at St. Louis Metropolitan Police Headquarters, Detective Alphonso Hayes's desk is littered with maps, printouts of MySpace profiles and various photos.
Over his shoulder, a pegboard is crowded with Polaroids.
On this board are the photographs of gang members who were shot and killed in the City of St. Louis.
It's almost completely covered.
Hayes says the most recent photo went up less than a week ago.
Twenty six hundred block at Madison, rolled in 60 Crips.
Mostly all these guys are dead or in jail.
All of these guys.
On the surface, the story of gang violence in St. Louis seems like a version of the L.A.
gang wars of the 1980s and '90s.
Bloods versus Crips shooting it out for drug turf.
In reality, it's much more random, with murders and shootings happening over standard teenage drama, things like jealous boyfriends or sports rivalries.
What would you say is the average age for a kid in a gang in St. Louis?
Probably 14.
You enter a stage in your life where fitting in with your friends is of the utmost importance.
They're highly unpredictable, and that's a scary thing.
There are just so many more gangs than there used to be, about 80 in St. Louis, with beefs often pitting block against block.
From Quarter all the way to Lee, that's our turf.
A guy who calls himself Woody and his buddy Fats are part of a Crip gang set in north St. Louis.
Who were the guys next to you?
Margarita.
From Lee to (unintelligible) is their turf.
Do you guys get along?
No, we don't get along with them.
It's been an on and off thing.
One minute they cool, the next minute they got hard, they bulk up, like they can't be touched.
Woody is only 16 and still in school.
Like most teenagers, he wants to fit in.
Except in this case, fitting in is a dangerous prospect.
You want to hear your name, too.
You want to be popular, it's like a popular thing.
I'm tired of hearing Fats' name all the time, where's my name?
Alright, well, give me the gun.
I'll go shoot at him.
That's what it is.
It's popularity.
You're trying to take out the big shots.
St.
Louis Police began noticing the trend several years ago, when they started assigning officers to basketball games and pep rallies.
They're not allowed to click up - what we call clicking up, coming in numbers and showing colors.
We got zero tolerance for them attending activities as a gang.
Lieutenant Ronnie Robinson is a watch commander in the Metro Police Department.
He says sometimes the only way to make headway with violent kids is to approach them on their level.
If I say, hey, you leave this kid alone right here.
He don't want to be part of this gang no more.
He belongs to us now.
He belongs to the police department.

If anybody touches him on the way to school or on the way to the store or approaches him in a negative way, and it comes back that you're involved or your gang involved, you're going to have a lot of problems with the St. Louis City Police Department.
The police are kind of like another gang.
Well, we're the most organized gang in the City of St. Louis.
We have to be.
But a boots-on-the-ground police presence isn't solving the problems of crumbling neighborhoods, no jobs and bad schools.
Carl Luss(ph)is a former member of the Blood street gang.
Sometimes, he says, the only way to keep the heat on or buy food is to join a gang.
I see a lot of people who struggle who got jobs.
They got to wait two weeks to get a $250, $300 check.
That's something I can't wait on, you know.
I'm used to fast money.
Luss has been arrested three times and faces 15 years if he gets caught again.
He's enrolled in a program called Community Partnership Restoration or Gang CPR, which tries to help convicted gang bangers break from their old neighborhoods.
My mom and them always tell me I'm scared to change, and I'm kind of starting to believe it.
That ain't got nothing to do with nobody calling me soft or no nerd or nothing.
It's just I'm so wrapped up in the lifestyle that I am in.
The Gang CPR program is one of the success stories in a struggle with few reasons to celebrate.
Several weeks ago, an off-duty firefighter was shot by a gang member who mistook him for a police officer, the 154th homicide so far this year, over 30 more than this time last year.
For NPR News, I'm Adam Allington in St. Louis.
Bobi Wine says the people who tortured him in an ambulance last month unscrewed an overhead light bulb to hide the beatings from the press.
Bobi Wine is a politician and a pop star in Uganda, where he's been an outspoken critic of the regime in power there.
After a contentious election to replace a parliamentarian, some protests turned violent.
Bobi Wine's driver was killed.
Bobi Wine says he was tortured by government forces.
He was eventually charged with treason.
Bobi Wine joins us in our studios.
He's been permitted to come to the United States for medical treatment.
Thanks so much for being with us.
Thank you very much for having me, Scott.
You came here on a crutch.
How are you feeling?
I'm alive.
That's the best answer.
I'm feeling pain in my back and my shoulders and various parts of my body.
But my spirit is high.
And I don't think about pain anymore.
This will be painful, I'm sure, to get you to recount.
But what happened?
How were you beaten and tortured?
So after the campaigns, I retreated - I returned to my hotel room.
There, we were attacked.
The military - the section of that military is called Special Forces Command, which is the section of the military that guards the president.
And it's led by the president's son.
And before I knew it, they all descended on me, kicked me, beat me everywhere and did despicable things to me.
They squeezed my testicles.
They hit me with gun butts.
When I screamed, they rapped my head again and hit me so hard in the back of the head until I was unconscious.
Your attorney Robert Amsterdam said this week that you would urge the U.S.
government to halt military funding to Uganda.
Now, as you know, the U.S.
supports the Ugandan army, so they can be deployed for international peacekeeping missions.
Respecting what you've been through, doesn't the U.S.
have powerful strategic reasons to support the Ugandan military?
All of us want a peaceful region.
And indeed, the Ugandan army plays a role.
And the U.S.
government plays a role funding them.
But it's important also for the U.S.
to know, especially the U.S.
taxpayer, that the money they give the Ugandan military is mainly used to torture Ugandans.
I would note that the gun that was used to shoot my driver is an American gun.
You're going to go back to Uganda?
Yes.
I'm going to go back to Uganda.
I don't have another home.
Uganda is my home.
That is where I was born.
And that is where I will be buried.
